dialogues.text: Endless barren landscape. No sign of life. The atmosphere is hazy, toxic-looking. Volcanoes erupt. Meteors bombard. Lightning strikes, concussing murky pools of water. Silen

dialogues.speaker: SUBTITLE
dialogues.text: Beamed ceilings and ostentatious fireplace. A few birthda cards on the mantel, two of them identical: "To Our Dear on His Fortieth Birthday." Charlie Kaufman, a fat, baldin man in a purple sweater with tags still attached, paces t room. His incantational voice-over carpets the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am old. I am fat. I am bald. My toenails have turned strange. I am repulsive. How repulsive? I don't know for I suffer from a condition called Body Dysmorphic Disorder. I am fat, but am I as fat as I think? My therapist says no, but people lie. I believe others call me Fatty behind my back. Or Fatso. Or, facetiously, Slim. But I also believe this is simply my own perverted form of self-aggrandizement, that no one really talks about me at all. What possible interest is an old, bald, fat man to anyone? I am repulsive. I have never lived. I blame myself. I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lonely two-lane highway cutting through swampland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As natural selection works solely by and for the good of each being, all corporeal and mental endowments will tend to progress towards perfection. Suddenly, a beat-up white van barrels around a curve.   I followed closely by an old green Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Laroche drives. He's a skinny man with no front teet The van is piled with bags of potting soil, gardening jun A Writings of Charles Darwin audio cassette case is on th seat next to Laroche.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is interesting to contemplate an entangled bank, clothed with many plants of many kinds, with birds singing... Laroche tries to contemplate the plants and birds whizzin by. Almost too late, he spots the Fakahatchee Strand Stat Preserve sign and makes a squealing right onto the dirt r turn-off. The cassette case flies from the seat and half- buries itself in an open bag of peat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nirvana blasts. Russell, Vinson, and Randy, three young Indian men, pass a joint and watch the erratic van ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laroche is asleep at the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crazy White Man is now Drowsy White Man. They share a stoned laugh.

dialogues.speaker: SUBTITLE
dialogues.text: Late night street. The click-click of typing. We move slowly up the building to the only glowing window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wistful) John Laroche is a tall guy, skinny as a stick, pale-eyed, slouch-shouldered and sharply handsome despite the fact that he is missing all his front teeth. In the window, lit by a single desk lamp, a woman types.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We glide over the desk piled with books about orchids, pa photo of Laroche tacked to an overwhelmed bulletin board, come to rest on a woman typing. It's Susan Orlean: pale, delicate and blond. We lose ourselves in her melancholy beauty. She turns to the camera and talks to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two years ago I went to Florida to meet Laroche after reading a small article about a white man and three Seminole men arrested with rare orchids they'd stolen out of a place called the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony, a ranger, drives along a dirt road past the Fakahat Strand State Preserve sign and enters the swamp. He sees white van and Ford parked ahead, spots a Seminole license plate on the Ford. He pulls over down the road, and whisp into his C.B.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got a Seminole, or Seminoles, in the swamp. I'm on Janes Scenic Drive just east of Logging Road Twelve. I repeat, Indians in the swamp. Tony waits for a response.   Nothing. TONY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indians in the swamp. Nothing still.   Tony clears his throat into the radio. RADIO VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you want me to say. TONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barry, Indians do not go on swamp walks. If there are Indians in the swamp, they are in there for a reason. No response. Tony glowers, gets out of the truck, watches the vehicles through binoculars. Nothing. He straightens his cap. Mosquitoes land on his neck, his nose, his lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaufman, wearing his purple sweater sans tags, sits with Valerie, an attractive woman in wire-rim glasses. They pi at salads. Kaufman steals glances at her lips, her hair, breasts. She looks up at him. He blanches, looks away. KAUFMAN (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm old.   I'm bald. I'm repulsive. VALERIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We think you're just great.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with studied modesty) Oh, thank you. Valerie absently rubs her nose.      Kaufman self-conscio rubs his nose in response. VALERIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we're thrilled you're interested. Valerie rubs her nose again. Kaufman pulls at his nostril A rivulet of sweat slides down his forehead. Valerie watc it. Kaufman sees her watching it. She sees him seeing her watching it. She looks at her salad. He quickly swabs. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thanks, wow. That's nice to hear. VALERIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a really unique voice. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, thanks. That's... I appreciate that. VALERIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very talented. Really. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.   Thank you.   Thanks. VALERIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up) So -- Kaufman's brow is dripping again.      He smiles, embarra KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sort of hot in here. VALERIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kindly) Yeah, it is a bit. So, why don't you tell me your thoughts on this crazy little project of ours. In one motion, Kaufman swabs his forehead and pulls a boo entitled The Orchid Thief from his bag. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First, I think it's a great book.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: VALERIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laroche is a fun character, isn't he? Kaufman nods, flips through the book, stalling. There's a smiling author photo of Susan Orlean on the inside back cover. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Orlean makes orchids so fascinating. Plus her musings on Florida, orchid poaching. Indians. Great, sprawling New Yorker stuff. I'd want to remain true to that, let the movie exist rather than be artificially plot driven. VALERIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, great, great. I guess I'm not exactly sure what that means. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Well... I'm not sure exactly yet either. So... y'know, it's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.    Okay.     Great.   So, um, what -- KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just, I don't want to compromise by making it a Hollywood product. An orchid heist movie. Or changing the orchids into poppies and turning it into a movie about drug running. Y'know? VALERIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, of course. We agree.        Definitely. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or cramming in sex, or car chases, or guns. Or characters learning profound life lessons. Or characters growing or characters changing or characters learning to like each other or characters overcoming obstacles to succeed in the end. Y'know? Movie shit. Kaufman is sweating like crazy now.       Valerie is quie moment. VALERIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, we thought maybe Susan Orlean and Laroche could fall in love during the course of --

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alienated journalist writes about passionate backwoods guy and he teaches her to love. I mean, it didn't happen, it wouldn't happen. It's Hollywood.

dialogues.speaker: SUBTITLE
dialogues.text: The office is decorated with potted flowers, Audobon post lots of books. Kaufman, nervous and sweaty, watches Margaret, a soulful development executive, unpack boxes. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So anyway I just wanted to stop by to congratulate you on your promotion. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, thanks again.   It's all so stupid. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's great. Your photo in the trades and everything. Pretty cool. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway.    Yeah. So what's up with you? KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm considering jobs. Mostly crap. There's one you might like, about flowers. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flowers?   Really? What is it? KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They want me to do an adaptation of a book called The Orchid Thief. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God! You're kidding?    I read that! I loved that book! Kaufman is thrilled; he's scored. Margaret pulls a copy o The Orchid Thief from her bookshelf. MARGARET (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, see, see! I'm not lying to you! KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I loved the book.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Charlie, orchids are the most amazing flowers. So complex. Margaret plops onto the couch next to Kaufman. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.   They're really great. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should take this job. Doesn't it sound exciting, to immerse yourself in a real subject and learn everything about it? Blake wrote about seeing heaven in a wild flower. And after you learn all this stuff, you can teach me! KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thrilled but controlled) That'd be fun. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, they're such beautiful flowers.    And so sexy. Y'know? (whispering) Did you know that orchid means -- KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Testicle.     I just read that. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrieks with delight) Testicle! Can you believe it! Margaret giggles happily.    Kaufman giggles weirdly. MARGARET (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear, it'd be fucking great for someone to have the testicles to make that book into a movie, man. Instead of this bullshit all the time. Something not about sex and violence and car chases and love stories, people learning profound lessons. Jesus, isn't nature enough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hot, dirty, miserable. Laroche leads the Indians through waist-high black water. He points out a turtle on a rock.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LAROCHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pseudemys floridana. Did you fellas know you fellas believe the world rests on the back of a turtle? Not you fellas specifically. Although, maybe you fellas specifically. That I can't speak to. The Indians ignore him. They trudge. Laroche spots something else, a dull green root wrapped around a tree. stops, circles the tree. His eyes widen in reverent awe. LAROCHE (cont'd) Polyrrhiza Lindenii.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ghost. The Indians come around. Laroche stares at a single beautiful, glowing white flower hanging from the tree. tenderly caresses the petals. Then, business-like: LAROCHE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut it down, Russell. Russell pulls out a hacksaw, begins sawing through the tr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaufman still sweats as he talks to Valerie. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...plus I love the idea of learning all about orchids. I really admire those guys who know everything about ants or fungus or whatever. I'd like to be more like that. See, I tend to write self- involved, self-loathing... even masturbatory stuff. VALERIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's wonderful, by the way. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. That's nice to hear. But I need to challenge myself as a writer. I've arrived at an age where I want to think about the world in a different way. VALERIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adapting someone else's work is certainly an opportunity to think differently.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. And I welcome the challenge of taking a small subject, like orchids, something that would never draw people into a theater and making that fascinating. I want to show people heaven in a wildflower. As Blake wrote.

dialogues.speaker: SUBTITLE
dialogues.text: A serious ten year old boy walks from cage to aquarium, studying the inhabitants. He turns to his frumpy mother, who's been following at a respectful distance. BOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any one at all, ma? She nods sweetly. The boy returns to his search.        H at a small turtle in an aquarium. BOY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want this then. MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hugging him) A wonderful choice! And spiritually significant! Did you know that Native Americans believe the whole world rests on the back of a turtle? BOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool!   I can't wait to tell the guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Laroche supervises, Randy, Russell, and Vinson saw thr tree branches supporting lovely flowering orchids. They unceremoniously stuff the flowers into bulging pillowcase

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaufman eats with Margaret.     Margaret raises a glass. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To a fucking awesome assignment, man. Kaufman, pleased, clicks glasses.     He takes a breath. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm going to an orchid show Sunday? For research? Maybe you'll come?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely. I think David, this guy I'm seeing, would enjoy it, too. He's a real naturalist. Okay if he comes along? KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (covering heartbreak) Yeah, of course. Sure. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to meet you anyway.     All I do is tell him how great you are. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thanks. That's nice to hear. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll like him. He's so honest and smart. It's rare to find someone in this town who thinks about things other than this fucking business, y'know? KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.     That's great.   He sounds great. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like the other day we were in bed discussing Hegel. Hegel! In bed! It was fucking amazing. Have you read much? KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know, a long time ago.   A bit.   Y'know. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, anyway, David and I were discussing his Philosophy of History and I was... The entrees arrive. MARGARET (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... struck by his notion that history is a human construct... Kaufman begins the laborious task of getting through his plate of food. He can no longer look up at Margaret. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. MARGARET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... that nature doesn't exist historically, but rather cyclically. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MARGARET (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So whereas human history spirals forward, building upon itself, nature...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaufman pulls a bunch of orchid books off the shelf, carr them to the register, along with a book on Hegel, which features an engraving of the philosopher on the cover. Kaufman waits in line and watches the tattooed female cas flirting with the handsome guy ahead of him. He studies their interaction, the way she looks at him. Her eyes, he lips. The guy leaves and the cashier waves Kaufman over. she rings him up, she expresses no interest in him. He's hurt and fixates on a sexy flower tattoo on her arm. She catches him, pulls down her sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony waits, sweaty and mosquito bitten.   The radio crack RADIO VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that Injun round-up going, Tony? TONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Barry, you fuckin'... Rustling near the parked cars. Tony tenses. Laroche steps from the swamp with the Indians, who haul the pillowcases TONY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got poachers. (into the radio, pleased) We got fuckin' poachers, Barry.   Ha! Tony jumps into the truck and turns it around.

dialogues.text: Orlean types. Her delicate fingers move with a pianist's grace across the computer keyboard. ORLEAN (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orchid hunting is a mortal occupation.

dialogues.text: An overturned boat and uprooted orchids float on the rive ORLEAN (V.O.)

dialogues.text: The Victorian-era orchid hunter William Arnold drowned on a collecting expedition.

dialogues.text: A man lies at the bottom of a cliff, clutching a flower. ORLEAN (V.O.)

dialogues.text: Schroeder fell to his death.

dialogues.speaker: SUBTITLE
dialogues.text: A man lies face down near an unplucked orchid. ORLEAN (V.O.)

dialogues.text: Endres was shot dead in Rio Hacha.

dialogues.text: An emaciated, limping, wheezing man with a makeshift band wrapped around his head, docks his boat. ORLEAN (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Augustus Margary survived toothache, rheumatism, pleurisy, and dysentery... Someone steps from behind a bush, stabs him, steals his b ORLEAN (V.O.) (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... only to be murdered when he completed his mission and traveled beyond Bhamo. The murderer sails down river. ORLEAN (V.O.) (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laroche loved orchids but I came to believe he loved the difficulty and fatality of getting them almost as much as he loved the orchids themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony steps out of his truck.   Laroche smiles warmly. TONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning. May I ask what you gentlemen have in those pillowcases? LAROCHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, you absolutely may.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Laroche goes back to directing the Indians.    Tony's con TONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm asking then. LAROCHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Okay then! Let's see... (peeking in bags) Five kinds of bromeliad, one peperomia, nine orchid varieties. About a hundred and thirty plants all told, which my colleagues have removed from the swamp. TONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're aware that it's illegal to remove plants or animals from state owned land? LAROCHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't forget these plants are all endangered, sir. Every one of them. TONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. Well, that's exactly the issue. This is a state preserve. LAROCHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, it is. (afterthought) Oh, and my colleagues are all Seminole Indians. Did I mention that? You're familiar, I'm sure, with the State of Florida v. James E. Billie. Tony nods, even though he has no idea. LAROCHE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you know that even though Seminole Chief Billie killed a Florida panther, one of, what, forty in the entire world? Laroche looks to the Indians for confirmation.       They LAROCHE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The state couldn't successfully prosecute him. Because he's an Indian and it's his right. As repugnant as you or I as white conservationists might find his actions. TONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But --

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LAROCHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to mention the failed attempts on three separate occasions to prosecute Seminoles for poaching palm fronds, which, I believe, they use to thatch the roofs of their traditional chickee huts. Laroche again looks to the Indians for confirmation. RUSSELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right. That's exactly what we use them for. Chickee huts. Tony looks at the Indians. RANDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. VINSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. RUSSELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. TONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I don't... I can't let you fellas go yet. Just hold on while I... (into radio) Hey, Barry, can I get some help? Barry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We watch Orlean as she drives out of the Miami Airport parking lot, onto the freeway, past congestion and billboards. Her mournful face glows beautifully, dramatically with golden sunlight. She talks to us. ORLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing in Florida seems hard or permanent. The developed places are just little clearings in the jungle, but the jungle is unstoppably fertile, everything is always growing or expanding. At the same time, the wilderness disappears before your eyes. Orlean gets quiet.   Her eyes tear.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lush color. A seven year old girl is gleeful as her paren push her on a swing. She watches from the air as her moth and father, deeply in love, kiss between pushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaufman gets out of his car with his books. Two teenage girls walk by. Kaufman watches as one whispers to the oth He thinks he hears the word "Fatso." The girls giggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaufman passes a hall mirror, regards himself glumly, and climbs the stairs. KAUFMAN (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am fat. I am repulsive.   I cannot bear my own reflection. At the landing Kaufman comes upon Donald, his identical t brother, on his back in pajama bottoms, opening a gift bo DONALD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you open your present from mom yet? KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with you? DONALD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My back. Kaufman nods vaguely, continues down the hall. Donald pul a purple sweater from the box, calls after Kaufman. DONALD (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Charles, you'll be glad, I have a plan to get me out of your house pronto. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A job is a plan. Is your plan a job? DONALD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (big build up) I'm gonna be a screenwriter!   Like you! Kaufman doesn't respond, enters his bedroom. DONALD (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you think this is just one of my get-rich-quick schemes. But I'm doing it right this time. I'm taking a seminar!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaufman lies face down on his mattress on the floor. DONALD (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only five hundred bucks! KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muffled by pillow) Screenwriting seminars are bullshit. Kaufman pulls a copy of Variety, open to a photo of Marga from under his pillow. He gets lost in the picture. DONALD (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In theory I agree with you. But this one is highly regarded within the industry. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donald, don't say "industry." Donald, now in the sweater, appears on all fours in the doorway. Kaufman puts the paper back under his pillow. DONALD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I forgot. Charles, this guy knows screenwriting. People from all over come to study his method. I'll pay you back, man. As soon as I sell -- KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me explain something to you. DONALD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody who says he's got "the answer" is going to attract desperate people. Be it in the world of religion -- DONALD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating his back) I just need to lie down while you explain this to me. Sorry. I apologize. (lies down, stares at ceiling) Okay, go ahead. Sorry. Okay. Go. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no rules to follow, Donald, and anybody who says there are, is just --

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DONALD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not rules, principles. McKee writes: "A rule says, you must do it this way.   A principle says, this works... and has through all remembered time." KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The script I'm starting, it's about flowers. No one's ever done a movie about flowers before. So, there're no guidelines, and that's good because -- DONALD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Flowers for Algernon? KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not about flowers.    And it's not a movie. DONALD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, okay, I never saw it.    Go ahead. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My point is, those teachers are dangerous if your goal is to do something new. And a writer should always have that goal. Writing is a journey into the unknown. It's not building a model airplane. Donald stares at the ceiling, fuming. Kaufman waits. Getting no no response, he pulls out his Hegel book and reads: KAUFMAN (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each being is, because posited, an op- posited, a conditional and conditioning, the Understanding completes these its limitations by positing the opposite... Kaufman's head is spinning. He puts the book down. Both brothers stare at the ceiling. Donald finally speaks DONALD

dialogues.text: McKee is a former Fulbright scholar. Are you a former Fulbright scholar, Charles?

dialogues.text: The young boy eats with his family. His father wears a backbrace, his sister is weak and anemic. Only his sweet mother pays attention as he chatters excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED

dialogues.text: Turtles are of the order Testudine! MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?    Testudine? BOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. And they're found on every continent! Except Antarptica! MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: The swampy part of the Fakahatchee is hot and wet and buggy and full of cottonmouth snakes and diamond back rattlers and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaufman drives down the same road surrounded by swamp.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ORLEAN (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... alligators and snapping turtles and poisonous plants and wild hogs and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orlean gets out of the car, knocks timidly on the shack d Ranger Mike Owen answers. MIKE OWEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie? It's Kaufman standing there. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tremulous) Yes. Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sky is overcast. Mike Owen leads Kaufman through a co swamp, which is completely dry. The two men walk easily o peaty ground. Kaufman, slathered with sun screen and cove head to foot in unnecessary protective clothing, tries to interested in Owen's lecture. MIKE OWEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So the whole ecosystem is six thousand years old. Five to six thousand years old. About that. Five or six. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. MIKE OWEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now the Fakahatchee is the largest of all the cyrpess strands, probably in the world. I don't know of any cypress strand bigger. It's about twenty miles long, or nineteen, nineteen to twenty, nineteen... and right here it's about five miles wide, four and a half, five. So, again, it's twenty miles long, three to five miles wide. And over here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike Owen holds a handful of peat.   Kaufman looks at it. MIKE OWEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The oldest carbon dating they've done on any of the peat out here is fifty-seven hundred years. That's with carbon-14. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MIKE OWEN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's in the right age where you can really date things accurately with carbon- 14, because it's half-life is fifty-five hundred years, so they must have found have of it gone and figured that... KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why isn't it wet? Orlean wrote about wading through black, corrosive water. She said it was the scariest experience of her life. And when I spoke to you on the phone, you said wear heavy boots, long pants and... MIKE OWEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's usually water. We've been going through a bit of a drought. Say, have you seen that movie, Medicine Man? That's a good movie about protecting nature. It shows there could be something important in a rain forest we don't even know about, like a cure for cancer. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not even hot. I was expecting it to be awful. Sun beating down, wading through water, looking out for snakes, wild hogs. I was thinking it would be dramatic. Alligators. Something! MIKE OWEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The alligators are over by the lakes. The temperature's a blessing for us. This time of year can get uncomfortably hot. (pointing excitedly) Green anole. Florida's most common. Kaufman looks down and sees a plain-looking little lizard hanging on a tree. Mike Owen jots it down in his notebook MIKE OWEN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I try to keep a log of sightings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike Owen drives.    Kaufman stares out the window at bor trees. ORLEAN (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It had been a hard day and I hadn't seen what I'd come to see. Maybe the ghost orchid was a ghost after all. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ORLEAN (V.O.) (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are certainly ghosts in the Fakahatchee -- ghosts of rangers who were murdered years ago by illegal plume hunters, and of loggers who were cut to pieces in fights, and for years there has been an apparition wandering the swamp, the Swamp Ape, which is said to be seven feet tall and seven hundred pounds and have the physique of a human, the posture of an ape, and the body odor of a skunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaufman and Owen stand by Kaufman's car. MIKE OWEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What Laroche did was wrong. Those flowers belong to all of us, all 250 million of us -- 250? I think it's up to 270 now -- And belonging to all of us means they belong to none of us. Nobody has a right to take them. Not me, not you, not John Laroche, not... Kaufman is desperate for something else.    He blurts: KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, um, Susan Orlean wrote about a legendary creature called a Swamp Ape. Have you ever heard stories or -- MIKE OWEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pissy) Tourist garbage! I don't know why people need to invent silly creatures to make nature fascinating. Isn't nature amazing enough? KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shamed) I just asked because she mentioned it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orlean, still dirty from the swamp, holds a phone to her and talks to us. She has cute little dirt smudges on her face. ORLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That night I called Laroche. ORLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) I didn't see anything but bare roots. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ORLEAN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I had this thought. Maybe the ghost orchid only blooms in the minds of people who've walked too long in the swamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orlean types. It's pouring and sheets of rain beat agains her window. She glances at her husband, across the room reading a book. She sighs, continues typing. ORLEAN (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I didn't say to him is that life seemed to be filled with things that were just like the ghost orchid -- wonderful to imagine and easy to fall in love with but a little fantastic and fleeting and out of reach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaufman drives down a Florida strip-malled highway. He passes a Barnes and Noble, a Burger King, a Starbucks. He parks in front of a California Pizza Kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaufman watches the waitresses. One approaches his booth. Her name badge reads: Caryn, Tampa, FL. She smiles at Kaufman as she looks right through him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A morose Kaufman sits on the bed reading The Orchid Thief KAUFMAN (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I didn't say to him was that life seemed to be filled with things that were just like the ghost orchid -- wonderful to imagine and easy to fall in love with but a little fantastic and fleeting and out of reach. Kaufman is deeply moved. He hi-lites the passage, then lo at the smiling photo of Orlean. He finds himself lost in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orlean, dirty from the swamp, is on the phone. LAROCHE (PHONE VOICE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat,clears throat) Jesus Christ, of course there are ghost orchids out there! I've stolen them! (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LAROCHE (PHONE VOICE) (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat, a cleared throat) You should have gone with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The line: "... then he cleared his throat and said: 'You should have gone with me.'" VALERIE (O.C.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautifully written. A really unique piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Busy lunch crowd. Valerie sits at a table with Orlean and open New Yorker magazine. ORLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.      Thanks very much. VALERIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're big fans. ORLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you. VALERIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Laroche is such a fun character. ORLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, John's a character all right. VALERIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's funny and fresh.     And sad in a way. ORLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, thanks. Thank you. VALERIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we were wondering, what's next? ORLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, um, Random House wants me to expand it into a book. So I'll be doing that. VALERIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there'll be more of Laroche? ORLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   More John, more orchids.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: VALERIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know, we'd really like to option it. ORLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) You want to make this into a movie? VALERIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laroche is such a fun character.   So...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laroche, wearing a Cleveland Indians T-shirt, drives craz thorugh the Hollywood Seminole reservation. Orlean holds LAROCHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit I'm a fun character. (beat) Who's gonna play me? ORLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to write it first. Someone's gotta write the screenplay. Most things never get made. It's premature to -- LAROCHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I should play me. Laroche swerves into a parking space in the nursery lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laroche and Orlean get out of the van. LAROCHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got all the right qualities. While you write, I'll take an acting class. A few young Indian guys are hauling bags of potting soil. They look at Laroche sourly. Laroche indicates the giant cartoon Indian on his T-shirt. LAROCHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wear this just to screw with 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laroche enters his office, looks at some papers on his de LAROCHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of them don't even bother calling me John anymore. It's "Crazy White Man" now. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LAROCHE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Crazy White Man" is a good title for the movie. Call the book "Crazy White Man." Or, I don't know, "Collector of Hearts" or something. Before Orlean can respond, Laroche picks up the phone and dials an impossibly long number. He waits, gestures for Orlean to sit on a chair piled high with junk. LAROCHE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't hurt anything. Orlean moves the junk over, shares the seat with it. LAROCHE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Yelling into phone) Hello? Hello? Hi? This is John Laroche from the Seminole Nursery. Sem-ih-nole! (to Orlean) How do you say Seminole in Spanish? (into phone) That's right, yes! Yeah, I want to order some more of those pink string beans! Pink string beans! (yelling) Pink String Beans! Pink String Beans! Buster appears in the door. LAROCHE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) I'll call back. (hangs up) Hey, Buster. BAXLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John. LAROCHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was trying to order some pink string beans from Argentina. BAXLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidding. LAROCHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figure just because Project Ghost Orchid is dead, we're not closing shop. BAXLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, John --

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LAROCHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll get into plant multiplication. Buy little ones, turn 'em into big ones, sell 'em at a profit. Simple plant multiplication for the masses. BAXLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, we're thinking maybe now's a good time for you to take a few weeks. LAROCHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need a vacation, Buster. BAXLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a good time.   Things are slow. Laroche stares at Buster.   Buster stares back. LAROCHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know, the guys on my crew here, all they do is smoke weed all day. I been meaning to talk to you about that. So if it's a question of productivity --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laroche weaves through traffic.   Orlean holds on. LAROCHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're gonna fire me. Goddamn politics. Crazy White Man's bad publicity. (pounds steering wheel) I can't believe I'm dealing with this! (pounds steering wheel) Like I could give a damn. If they fire me, I'll sue. I already did some legal research on this when I was doing the other shit. They can't fire me. And I ain't going to quit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray skies. Kaufman drives his rental car: he looks at th Seminole Nursery, the Collier County Courthouse, Laroche' house. He drives through swampy terrain. He walks around an orchid show, he attends a slide-show orchid lecture. I all dull. He ends up sitting on a bench on an empty beach staring out at the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orlean dials the phone.   It rings for a long time.    Fi

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LAROCHE (PHONE VOICE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (groggy) Yeah? ORLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, it's Susan. (waits for response) Orlean. (waits) So, I was just wondering if you might be willing to talk some more. LAROCHE (PHONE VOICE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about? Orlean rolls her eyes. ORLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, John, I'm trying to put together a book. Don't just abandon me down here. LAROCHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm no longer interested in orchids. I'm pursuing other avenues. I apologize for any inconvenience this might cause you. Orlean is silent, taps her fingers on the bedside table. LAROCHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for your time. Laroche hangs up. Orlean sits there for a moment, flips through her list of orchid collector names.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaufman sits on the bench, looking out at the ocean. An attractive, spandexed couple skate by, chatting in German He watches the woman, hoping for a look, for something. H doesn't get it. They're gone. A tan older man sits on the bench, lights a cigarette. Kaufman continues to look at t ocean, even though he feels the guy's eyes on him. He doesn't want to engage. GUY ON BENCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could use the rain, huh? Kaufman nods, looking at the ocean.      Pause. GUY ON BENCH (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you from around here? Kaufman shakes his head "no."   Pause.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GUY ON BENCH (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So where then? KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: California. GUY ON BENCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excitedly) Yeah? I'm moving to L.A. I just wrote a screenplay. I sent it to a lot of agents. But if they turn me down, I'll go there and market it myself. I used to be in marketing in New York, so I know exactly how to sell this thing. (beat) Where's a nice place to live if you don't have a car? KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You kind of need a car. I guess West Hollywood would be okay. GUY ON BENCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you recommend West Hollywood then. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not recommending it. Pause. GUY ON BENCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I moved down here for a change, and I wrote the screenplay. Just like that. It's a great idea. The old guy waits for a response.    He gets none. GUY ON BENCH (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about a mob guy, but it's not your regular mob story. There's a twist. A cop tells this mob guy's wife that the mob guy's cheating on her. But the truth is, the cop's lying because he wants her for himself. See, they used to go together in high school. (waits for response, then:) You know anything about screenplays? Kaufman shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GUY ON BENCH (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the object is to make people think you're going in one direction, then you twist it to keep 'em surprised. I came up with all these amazing twists out of nowhere. Well, not nowhere. (beat) I'm a born again Christian. (beat) You have faith? KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.     Not really. GUY ON BENCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't believe in anything? Kaufman shrugs. GUY ON BENCH (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how you can look out at this beautiful ocean and not believe there's an intelligence that created it. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. GUY ON BENCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you can't know until you experience it. That requires accepting Jesus Christ as your Lord and Savior. Believe me. Lookit, if I was to show you a bottle of clear liquid and told you it was vodka, how would you know if it really was or if it was water? There's only one way. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd smell it. GUY ON BENCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed) No. You can't smell vodka.    You'd have to taste it, right? KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could be poison.    I don't know you. GUY ON BENCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry) Look, let's go with the analogy I'm drawing here. It's not poison. Okay? (resuming control) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GUY ON BENCH (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you'd have to taste it to know. Right? That's my point. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. GUY ON BENCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all I'm saying. (beat) So West Hollywood, huh? I think I'll make it out this year. Because how long can you look at an ocean, y'know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan Orlean talks to various orchid enthusiasts, visits nurseries, sits in lecture halls, attends orchid shows, s in the library reading orchid books. She is bored and distracted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stewardess places a cup and an airline-sized bottle of vodka down in front of a lost Kaufman. He smiles at her. response. He opens the bottle and smells the vodka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaufman sits in the back seat and stares out the window. driver looks at him a couple of times in his rearview mir KAUFMAN (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have failed. I have nothing to say.    I am fat. I am not a writer. DRIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kaufman, do you mind if I ask what type of work you do for Sony? KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a writer. DRIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed) A song writer? KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm a screenwriter. DRIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, wow! Good for you. You mind if I ask what your movie's about?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about flowers. No response.   Kaufman tries to make it interesting. KAUFMAN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about this poacher who steals orchids out of a swamp. DRIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard about that!   Drug flowers, right? KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   That's it. DRIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard about that! That's great! Action-adventure is my favorite genre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaufman enters with his bags and heads to the stairs. Donald, typing furiously at his desk, looks up. DONALD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was Florida, man? KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (climbing the stairs) Okay. DONALD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool! Hey, my script's going amazing! Right now I'm working out an Image System. Bob calls it an invaluable asset. Because of my multiple personality theme, I've chosen the motif of broken mirrors to show my protagonist's fragmented self. Bob teaches that an Image System greatly increases the complexity of an aesthetic emotion. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sound like you're in a cult. Kaufman disappears upstairs. DONALD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's just good writing technique. (types, then:) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DONALD (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I made you a copy of McKee's Ten Commandments. I've posted one over both our work areas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaufman tears down MCKEE'S TEN COMMANDMENTS. Donald appea backlit in the doorway and seems oddly threatening. DONALD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't have done that. They look at each other.    Donald breaks the tension, sm DONALD (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause it's extremely helpful. (lies down on floor) Hey, any sign of that Swamp Ape? KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no Swamp Ape. It was invented for people who can't find the actual world fascinating. Y'know? DONALD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, okay. I didn't know that. Sorry. Hey, I got a song! "Happy Together." I was worried about putting a song in a thriller, but Bob says, Casablanca, the greatest screenplay ever written, did exactly that. Mixed genres. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to go to bed, Donald.    I haven't slept in a week. DONALD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Donald remains on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: Mishmash of images: alligators snapping, Laroche jabberin Orlean typing, 19th century orchid poachers slogging, orc blooming, Mike Owen lecturing. KAUFMAN (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... so we open the swamp... okay, flashback to young Laroche had turtles... Okay, Susan says What Is Passion? And okay we open on a swamp and suddenly a white van comes tearing around...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaufman lies half-awake in bed, sweating, his eyes dartin back and forth. He looks over at the clock. It's 3:32. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn it. Donald snores happily off-screen.   Kaufman switches on a lamp, pulls The Orchid Thief from his bag, flips through There are now many yellow hi-lited passages. He reads one KAUFMAN (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are too many ideas and things and people, too many directions to go. I was starting to believe the reason it matters to care passionately about something is that it whittles the world down to a more manageable size. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such sweet, sad insights.   So true. Kaufman flips to the glowing, smiling author photo. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're... I like looking at you. He stares at the photo.   Its smile broadens.    It talks ORLEAN PHOTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like looking at you, too.   Charlie. The photo smiles warmly at him.   Kaufman begins to jerk- He closes his eyes. Then: Kaufman and Orlean are in his bed together, making love. She smiles at him throughout. They finish. Then: Kaufman is alone in bed, heaving. He looks at the still smiling photo. It somehow seems sleepy now. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how to do this. I'm afraid I'll disappoint you. You've written a beautiful book. I can't sleep. I'm losing my hair. I'm fat and repulsive -- ORLEAN PHOTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh. You're not. Whittle it down, focus on one thing in the story, find the thing you care passionately about and write about that.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Kaufman studies her delicate, melancholy face.      He's ORLEAN PHOTO (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweet, flirty smile) I figured there might be something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaufman paces and talks animatedly into his mini-recorder KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Susan Orlean, delicate, fragile, beautiful, haunted by loneliness, typing at her desk. She looks at the camera and talks to us: "John Laroche is a tall guy, skinny as a stick, pale-eyed, slouch- shouldered..." Donald enters in his underwear, pours coffee. DONALD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hey. DONALD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem chipper. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm good.     I have some new ideas. DONALD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool. Me too. I'm putting in a chase sequence now. The killer flees on horseback with the girl. The cop is after them on a motorcycle. It's like a battle between motors and horses. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all still one person, right? DONALD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, hey, that's the big pay-off. KAUFMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nice) Well, it sounds exciting. DONALD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, man. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orlean drives through swampy landscape.   She talks to us ORLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose what I'd been doing in Florida was trying to understand how people found order and contentment and a sense of purpose in the universe by fixing their sighs on one single desire. Now I was also trying to understand how someone could end such intense desire without a trace. Orlean stops at a payphone and dials.   It rings for a wh LAROCHE (PHONE VOICE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (groggy) Yeah what? ORLEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, John, it's Susan. LAROCHE (PHONE VOICE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want your writing to be original. You want to have an original voice like Neil Simon or Nora Ephron. Well, let me tell you something, my friends. The key to originality is not eccentricity. A guy behind Kaufman gives an appreciative "mmmm."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's late. The audience is tired, but still attentive. No Kaufman takes serious notes. McKee, energetic as ever, we his sweater tied around his shoulders. We stay firmly planted on his face as he talks and talks. MCKEE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long speechs are antithetical to the nature of cinema. The Greeks called it stykomythia -- the rapid exchange of ideas. A long speech in a script, say a page long, requires that the camera hold on the actor's face for a minute. Look at the second hand on your watch as it makes one complete rotation around the clock face and you'll get an idea of how intolerable that would be for an audience. The ontology of the screen is that it's always now and it's always action and it's always vivid. Life is rarely vivid. And that's an important point. We are not recreating life on the screen. Writers are not tape recorders. Have you ever eavesdropped on people talking in a coffee shop? Then you know how dull and tedious real conversation is. Real people are not interesting. There's not a person in this world -- and I include myself in this -- who would be interesting enough to take as is and put in a movie as a character.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
